change.item: Batch update to change repository name, subject links, preferred citation, and user restrictions.

did.unittitle: Indiana University Arts Administration Program records
did.abstract: The Indiana University Arts Administration Program, part of the School of Public and Environmental Affairs on the Bloomington campus, was conceived in 1970 with the first students beginning the program in the fall of 1972. The program is of an inter-disciplinary nature, drawing on the cooperative efforts of SPEA, the Department of Theatre and Drama, and the Schools of Business, Music, Fine Arts, and Health, Physical Education, and Recreation, with the goal of providing a balance of artistic and business concerns, of theory and hands-on experience. The collection consists of conference and symposium files, correspondence, committee files, general administrative records, and files related to alumni and student projects.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Most files in the Alumni and student files series still contain grades and social security numbers. Researchers wanting access to these files will need to alert archives staff well in advance so that these restricted records can be removed.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The planning of the Arts Administration Program began in spring of 1970, and the first students were admitted into the program in the fall of 1972 to begin their studies in pursuing a Masters of Arts degree. The goal of the program was to train students with a balance of artistic and business concerns, of theory and hands-on experience. To gain these valuable skills and experience students had to complete coursework in arts administration, business, and management fields through the Kelley School of Business, Jacobs School of Music, School of Public and Environmental Affairs, Department of Theatre and Drama, School of Health, Physical Education, and Recreation, and the Henry Radford Hope School of Fine Arts. In addition to their coursework, students were required to complete an internship which would give them a hands-on experience in real world situations.
Today the Arts Administration Program has expanded, and now enrolls students at all levels, from undergraduate certificates and degrees to minors for doctoral students.

Students that have graduated from the program have gone on to hold positions at a number of very prodigious organizations. The Arts Administration Program can claim alumni at Carnegie Hall, Smithsonian Institution, American Symphony Orchestra League, Ministry of Education and Culture of Cyprus, Kentucky Derby Museum, and Indiana University Arts Museum, to name but a few.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is organized into six series: Conferences, symposiums, and meetings; Funding; Correspondence; Committee files; Administrative files; and Alumni and student files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Arts Administration Program records are organized into six series. The first series, Conferences, symposiums, and meetings (1976-1997, undated), has materials organized into these three themes, which are then arranged chronologically by event date. The conferences and symposiums represent events which have been organized and sponsored by the Program and which are open to anyone interested in attending. On the other hand, the meetings are specifically for Program members.
The second series, Funding (1973-1995, undated), is organized chronologically and consists of materials dealing with grant proposals and applications, fundraising, and budgets.
The Correspondence series (1991-1995), is arranged chronologically and consists of invitations, replies, and thank-you letters in regard to Program events.
The forth series, Committee files (1979-1985, undated) consists of materials related to those committees and councils with which Program members were participants or associated with in some way.

The Administrative files series (1972-1998, undated) is organized into related material dealing with courses and seminars, program history, and folders containing Arts Administration (AADM) related activates.

The sixth series, Alumni and student files (1973-2006, undated) is organized into a variety of topics such as Alumni Directories, student projects, internship information, student files for Arts Administration minors, and files on all students who graduated from the Program organized by year and last name, and then chronologically. The graduating student files still contain grades and social security numbers and will need to be reviewed by an archivist prior to releasing them for research.
Audiovisual materials are listed where they would fall in the intellectual organization of the collection but are physically located in Box 9.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Six photographs of the International Arts Administration Seminar (Germans), July 10-14, 1994. The images are of reception attendees.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyrights for records originating with Indiana University administrative units, departments, and other offices are held by the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Indiana University Arts Administration Program records, Collection C374, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Transferred to the Archives by the Arts Administration Program in 2002, 2004, and 2007.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Duplicate programs and questionnaires for symposiums were removed. Materials containing student, faculty, and visiting speakers SSNs were removed and shredded.
